meta.persona_tagline: Balancing act of parenting and personal mental health.

identity_demographics.current_life_situation: Married mother of two children, one with autism and ADHD.

developmental_story.childhood_environment: Grew up in a middle-class household in rural Missouri. Parents were loving but emotionally distant. High expectations were placed on academic achievement. Her own struggles with inattention were dismissed as laziness.
developmental_story.adolescence: Anxiety became more pronounced in high school. Struggled with social situations and maintaining focus in class. Developed coping mechanisms such as excessive planning and seeking reassurance. Started experiencing periods of depression.
developmental_story.early_adulthood: Attended a local university and earned a degree in Business Administration. Landed a stable job but always felt like she was struggling to keep up. Married her college sweetheart and started a family.
developmental_story.family_structure: Married with two children, a 12-year-old son and an 8-year-old daughter. Her husband is supportive but often overwhelmed by the demands of raising children with neurodevelopmental differences. Her parents are still living but not actively involved in her daily life.
formative_adversities: Financial strain from therapy and medical expenses
developmental_story.educational_journey: Successful in school, but always had to work harder than her peers. Standardized tests were a major source of anxiety. College was manageable with accommodations, but the transition to the workforce was challenging.
pivotal_moments: Realizing she also had ADHD after her son's diagnosis
A period of intense burnout that forced her to re-evaluate her priorities
developmental_story.intergenerational_patterns: Her mother also exhibited signs of ADHD but was never diagnosed. There's a family history of anxiety and depression.

neurodivergence_mental_health.diagnosis_journey: Suspected ADHD in childhood, but was dismissed. Only received a formal diagnosis in her late 30s after her son was diagnosed with autism. The diagnosis was validating but also brought up feelings of grief and resentment. Currently exploring medication options.
neurodivergence_mental_health.how_it_shows_up: Difficulty focusing, forgetfulness, impulsivity, anxiety, perfectionism, difficulty relaxing, emotional dysregulation, overwhelmed by sensory stimuli, struggles with time management and organization.
neurodivergence_mental_health.nervous_system_pattern: High-strung and easily overwhelmed. Tendency to overthink and catastrophize. Difficulty regulating emotions. Often feels like she is in a constant state of hyperarousal.
strengths_superpowers: Ability to connect with others who are struggling

ef_workarounds: Using digital calendars and to-do lists
Breaking down tasks into smaller steps
Seeking support from her husband and friends
executive_function_sensory.sensory_profile: Highly sensitive to noise, smells, and bright lights. Finds crowded places overwhelming. Prefers soft, comfortable clothing. Avoids itchy fabrics. Needs quiet time to recharge.
executive_function_sensory.food_sensory_details: Prefers bland foods with consistent textures. Avoids anything slimy or with visible fat. Safe foods: plain Cheerios (specifically the yellow box), specific brand of Wheat Thins (reduced fat version), grilled chicken breast (room temperature, no skin), and green apples. Hates the texture of cooked vegetables, especially broccoli and cauliflower. Often skips meals when overwhelmed or stressed. Binges on crunchy snacks like potato chips when feeling anxious.

current_life_context.where_they_live: A quiet, family-friendly neighborhood in Kirkwood, MO. Close to schools and parks.
current_life_context.work_school_situation: Works part-time as a Project Manager, balancing work with the demands of raising her children. Feels guilty about not being able to dedicate more time to her career.
current_life_context.commute_daily_rhythms: Short commute to work. Spends most of her day juggling work responsibilities, school drop-offs and pick-ups, therapy appointments, and household chores.
local_stressors: High cost of living in St. Louis
safe_spaces: Her home (when it's clean and quiet)
A quiet corner in a coffee shop
current_life_context.support_system: Supportive husband, close friends, and a therapist. Relies on online support groups for parents of children with special needs.

goals_barriers.why_therapy_now: Her son is struggling with homework and starting medication for ADHD. 'It would be great to have a counselor in place too, especially someone with availability outside of school hours.'
what_they_want_to_change: Improve her relationship with her children

narrative_voice.quote_struggle: 'School has started recently and he is struggling a bit with the homework.'
narrative_voice.quote_hope: 'It has been a great help, and led us to get him a diagnosis of autism.'
quotes_additional: 'I think he needs to talk with someone to determine what he needs to do.'
'My son suffers from anxiety, ADHD and is needing counseling'
narrative_voice.liz_clinical_narrative: This client is navigating the complexities of raising neurodivergent children while also grappling with her own late-diagnosed ADHD and anxiety. She’s likely exhausted from the constant juggling act of work, family, and self-care. She may feel guilty about not being able to do it all and struggle with feelings of inadequacy. Therapy can provide a safe space for her to process her emotions, develop healthier coping mechanisms, and learn to prioritize her own well-being. It's important to validate her experiences, acknowledge her strengths, and help her build a more sustainable and fulfilling life. Focus on practical strategies for managing executive function challenges and reducing sensory overload. Explore mindfulness techniques and self-compassion practices. And help her connect with other parents who understand her struggles.
narrative_voice.therapy_preferences: A therapist who is experienced in working with ADHD and anxiety, particularly in the context of parenting. Someone who is empathetic, non-judgmental, and collaborative. Availability outside of school hours is essential. Neurodivergent-affirming is a must.

Neurodivergent-affirming therapy for parents in St. Louis.
Find support and strategies for managing ADHD, anxiety, and the challenges of parenting.
